summary: This is a transcript of a voluntary sworn interview conducted by DOJ OIG Special Agents with a Federal Bureau of Prisons Correctional Systems Officer (CSO) regarding the death of inmate Jeffrey Epstein on August 10, 2019, and the surrounding circumstances at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC). The interview focuses on the officer's duties, shift schedules, inmate movement procedures, count protocols, and the removal of Epstein's cellmate, Efrain Reyes, on August 9, 2019.

events.title: OIG Interview of BOP Officer
events.description: DOJ OIG Special Agents interview a BOP Correctional Systems Officer as part of the investigation into Epstein's death and surrounding circumstances.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC), 150 Park Row, New York, NY
keyFacts: Epstein's cellmate, Efrain Reyes, was removed from the MCC at 8:38 a.m. on August 9, 2019, after going to court and did not return, leaving Epstein without a cellmate.

The interviewed officer, who worked in both custody and R&D, stated that if staff knew an inmate was WAB (With All Belongings) and not returning, and knew Epstein required a cellmate, they should have taken action to assign a new cellmate.

There were significant count discrepancies in the SHU on the night of August 9-10, 2019, because inmate Fernandez was moved to a dry cell in R&D but not keyed out of the SHU, leading to incorrect counts at 4:00 p.m., 10:00 p.m., and midnight.

The officer expressed that institutional problems included a lack of training, poor communication, and low morale, and that staff often follow incorrect practices because they are not properly trained.
The officer believed Epstein died by suicide, had no knowledge of anyone assisting him or causing his death, and had no reason to believe cameras were intentionally knocked offline.
